climbs.name: Trix
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Tony Grice, February 2006

content.description:
This variation climbs the best part of Quaking Oats (which is a fun crack/stemming corner) then moves right and climbs the face of a pillar past 2 bolts to the top. This exposed and exciting finish, combined with the lower crack/corner, makes for a great pitch.

Descent: scramble/downclimb right (south) with a bit of class 4.
content.location: Located on the far right side of the West face.

climbs.name: Quaking Oats
climbs.fa: Todd Swain, Cyndie Bransford, and Alan Bartlett, February 1992

content.description:
Face climb into a right-facing corner, follow this up to a low-angle gully/trough that leads to the top.

Descend by downclimbing/scrambling off to the right (south). A bit of class 4.
content.location: This climb is located on the far right side of the west face.

climbs.name: Oat Cuisine
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Todd Gordon, November 1989.

content.description: Climb a left slanting thin crack/flake that passes over a bulge with somewhat poor protection.

climbs.name: Frosted Flakes
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Dave Mayville, May 2013

content.description:
Climb flakes up to a steep slab with 3 bolts, then climb over a bulge past another bolt to an easier face to the top.

This climb is very well protected and a good choice if you're breaking into the 10+ grade or working on redpointing a 10+.

At the first bolt you can climb straight up (10+) or move right and back left (5.9). The moves past the second and third bolts are intricate and crimpy (10+), but you're very well protected. The bulge at the fourth bolt and the upper face are relatively easy.
content.protection:
4 bolts, CDs to 3.5 inches, including #0 and #2 metolius

2-bolt belay/rappel anchor. 70 feet

I used a #1 camalot at the start, then a #4 camalot in the crack on the right.

I equalized a #0 and #2 metolius in the horizontal crack just below the first bolt.

You can get a #2 camalot in the horizontal crack below the fourth bolt, and a #1 camalot in the horizontal above the fourth bolt near the top.
content.location: From the main road parking/pullout walk around the left side of the West Face to the Northeast Face. 5 min. approach

climbs.name: Coco Puff
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Frank Bentwood, and Kelly Vaught, May 2013

content.description:
This slightly overhanging sport climb is located on the Northeast Face. If you utilize all the stemming posibilities of the lower section, the route is 5.10b. If you avoid the stemming and climb the wall directly, the bottom section is 5.11b.

Although this is a tightly bolted sport route, beware that if you blow some of the clips, you may hit the adjacent ledge/wall...so to lead this one you should be solid at the grade!
content.location: From the main road parking at the pullout, walk left around the West face to the Northeast Face. 5 min appoach time.

climbs.name: Cereal Killer
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Todd Swain, November 1989

content.description: Climb steep flakes to start (maybe 5.7?) then move right to a vertical crack which peters out. An easy but unprotected face takes you to the top.

climbs.name: Buckwheat
climbs.fa: Todd Swain and Dick Peterson, October 1991

content.description:
This is on a low, brown buttress at the far right of the west-side of  Cereal Rock.

On the left-side, climb to an alcove, move right and then up past a bolt.
content.protection:
This is on a low, brown buttress at the far right of the west-side of  Cereal Rock.

On the left-side, climb to an alcove, move right and then up past a bolt.

Standard rack.

content.description:
Left crack up the tall narrow pillar in middle of the west face, to adjacent left of Quaking Oats.  Sustained awkward sketchiness up thru the low crux.

Some might balk at the sound of that.  But def interesting moves.  The black juggy portion just above the crux, where you really want to crank down on, it moves.  So crank down, not out.  Quaking Oats finishes the same as Alfalfa.
content.location:
Walk off via downscramble to climber's right as noted in Bob's

photo

.
